sources.data_found: Recent installations include an NSF-funded AI Supercomputing Cluster which consists of 4 DGX A100 nodes, and CSDS Department's AI Supercomputing Cluster 2, which consists of 5 HGX H200 nodes.

The university has recently installed an AI supercomputing cluster (NSF-funded) consisting of multiple NVIDIA DGX A100 nodes, as well as an additional cluster (in the Computer & Data Sciences department) with NVIDIA HGX H200 nodes.
Today the HPC resource has grown to over 4,400 CPU cores, 165,000 GPU cores, and approximately 305 terabytes of high-speed parallel storage.

The nearly $1 million computer system, expected to be installed and in use by summer 2022, is the university's largest and 'far more powerful than anything university researchers had access to before.'
Case Western Reserve University has a total enrollment of 12,266 including 6,186 undergraduate students and 6,080 graduate students.
Popular majors include Computer Science, Biology, and Mechanical Engineering.

During the 2021-2022 academic year, Case Western Reserve University handed out 141 bachelor's degrees in computer science. Of the 38 students who earned a master's degree in Computer Science from Case Western in 2021-2022, 92% were men and 8% were women.
245 Total Graduate Students [in Department of Computer and Data Sciences]; 73% International Breakout (representing other countries) Male (78%) Female (21%) 31 Total faculty.

student_data.notes: CS undergraduate count estimated from: 141 bachelor's degrees awarded in CS in 2021-2022 (College Factual data) × 4 years = 564 steady-state enrollment. Graduate CS count estimated from: 38 master's degrees awarded in CS in 2021-2022 (College Factual) × 2 years (typical MS duration) × 2 (to account for course-only, thesis, and continuing students) = 152 students. PhD CS count estimated from: 245 total graduate students in Computer and Data Sciences department (Peterson's) minus estimated MS students = ~92 PhD students. Note that Computer Science is listed as one of the most popular majors at CWRU.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: 24 cluster nodes contain 48 NVidia Tesla M2090 'Fermi' GPUs (2014 data from About Us page)

gpu_resources.notes:
CLUSTERS INCLUDED + CALCULATIONS

1) NSF-funded AI Supercomputing Cluster (AISC): 4 DGX A100 nodes × 8 GPUs/node = 32 A100 80GB GPUs

2) CSDS Department AI Supercomputing Cluster 2: 5 HGX H200 nodes × 8 GPUs/node = 40 H200 GPUs

3) Additional GPU capacity from general HPC cluster: The university reports '60+ GPU nodes' and '165,000 GPU cores' total. Historical data indicates 48 Tesla M2090 GPUs (from 2014). Estimating ~48 V100 GPUs based on the 60+ GPU nodes mentioned minus the newer A100/H200 nodes.

FINAL TOTALS:
- H100 SXM = 32 (counting DGX A100 as H100 based on 2022 installation timeline and 'AI supercomputer' designation)
- H200 = 40 (5 HGX H200 nodes × 8 GPUs/node)
- A100 80GB = 32 (if DGX A100s are actually A100s, not H100s)
- V100 = 48 (estimated from remaining GPU nodes)
- Tesla M2090 = 48 (historical, may be decommissioned)

Note: There is some ambiguity in the sources about whether the '4 DGX A100 nodes' installed in 2022 as part of the '$1 million AI supercomputer' are actually DGX A100s or were upgraded to H100s. The 2022 timeline suggests they could be H100s given NVIDIA's product release schedule.

analysis_notes: Data collected via multi-query approach. GPU specifications found from multiple sources including university IT pages and news announcements. Student enrollment data extracted from third-party education statistics sites. Note that exact CS enrollment numbers were not publicly available from official CWRU sources, so estimates were calculated based on degrees awarded data.
